38886459.review:
Note: [u]This game was purchased by the reviewer during a steam sale[/u]

[h1]Urgency and Purpose[/h1]

Those are the two words that I would use to describe my experience playing the game “Near Death”. To survive you must have a purpose for task at hand and do so with urgency. Every second spent out in the open away from a source of heat brings you another moment closer to death. 

There is no need for large animals or scary monsters hunting you when the wind and the dropping temperature of the air you breath can kill you just as fast! As the game progresses the intensity of the wind literally pushes your player character around the environment as you struggle from one location to the next. 

“Near Death” has great atmosphere and soundtrack. There is basic crafting and inventory management. It also forces you to read a map and the terrain. As with real life, before GPS on every phone anyway, there is no blinking dot on the map to tell you where you are.  It can be easy to get lost in the near white out conditions and perish.

The only downside to this game is the relatively short time it takes to complete. Although, I say it is a short game I don’t mean it to sound like I feel cheated in any way. There is a story to follow and a mission to complete. Extending the story any longer would have detracted from the Urgency that you feel while playing. 

Was it worth the cost of the game? For myself, who purchased the game during a Steam Winter sale the answer is absolutely. Is it worth the full $15? That would be harder to say. Would I still have enjoyed it as much? Without a doubt! If you aren’t convinced pick it up during the next sale.

38016245.review:
A grind-free survival game that's actually about survival. No amassing vaults full of items, no base-building, it's just you versus the cold. There are a limited amount of supplies, limited visibility, and limited survival time outside of shelter.

Best played with all the lights out, headphones on, and on the hardest setting.

If I had not played it through on the hardest setting the very first time I wouldn't have had the same experience. Playing on Condition 1 is a must for the full experience. Lower levels make it more like a walking simulator, so save that for after you've done your Condition 1 run if you just want to explore, or you will spoil the game. It's all about the struggle to find things and not knowing how much of what is out there or where to find it and doing it on the fly.

38009425.review:

[h1] Шёл на посадку самолет…
Не получилось… Приземлиться…
Пошёл он на второй заход…

-Мы летим, наш самолёт терпит падение. Вылазим из него. И... И... Ну... Мы в 2 раза больше, чем кабина самолёта...

-Лут. Его дохрена, но его столько не надо. Я прошёл игру, потратив ну 5 баллонов топлива, для печки, и заколотив 5 окон.
-Сложность. Я играл на средней. Это линейная игра. Скучная, однообразная. Хз, зачем её проходить на харде, это же не "Симулятор выживания".
-Геймплей просто 11 из 10. Идём из одного конца карты в другой, и так несколько раз, типа добываем всё необходимое для отправки. Так всю игру. 
Вот ты приносишь очередные вещи, надеешься "ИГРА, НУ КОНЧИСЬ", нет тебя отправляют в соседнюю страну за картой, выбора нет, ты опять ходишь туда-сюда.
Периодически, чтобы игра не проходилась за 30 минут, надо забегать в помещения и греться. 
Периодически, чтобы игра не проходилась за 30 минут, мы идём против бури, и ГГ идёт 10 метров в 30 секунд. Приходится бросать груз, и бежать греться, а потом возвращаться. 
Периодически, чтобы игра не проходилась за 30 минут, нам надо чатиться с чуваком на другом конце провода. Гоняем кучу воды, шутки шутим, в -100 градусов. Именно так и поступали бы люди. "Как дела? Чё делаешь? Ахахха, лол, рили? 
А, да у меня тут трабл, самолёт упал, ага. А Анька как? Да ладно? И кто? Мальчик, девочка? Двойня? Афигеть. А Лёха как поживает? ДА ЛАДНО? А Маринка как отреагировала?"

ЧЕГО? ЩИТО? ВАТАФАК? От какой игры эта инфа? Погоды тут 2:
1-Буря, когда персонаж идёт как черепаха
2-Просто метель, снег.

Указатель показывает в одну сторону, сам объект, на который указывает указатель на 90 градусов левее или правее. Из-за этих указателей я половину времени искал, куда мне бежать.

37606844.review:
While many good horror/scifi games use this sort of setting (Black Snow, Penumbra, The Thing), Antarctica doesn’t need monsters or a horror tone to be interesting and dangerous. 

In Near Death, the elements are your only adversary, and they are formidable enough. The cold will kill you in a minute or two. It’s conveyed with flair and immersive atmosphere. See if you can play this game without shivering at the sound of the wind howling through broken windows while you scavenge for meagre resources or huddle beside an oil heater for warmth. Or try to walk a short distance between two stations in the middle of a blizzard, the gale-force winds blowing you off-course. It’s a great game to play in winter, or in summer if you want to forget about the heat.

With streamlined survival and scavenging mechanics, the game slowly raises the challenge, although it never gets terribly complex. You’ll need to set up light beacons and rope guides to get between some of the more distant buildings, and you’ll need to prioritise resources to enable you greatest mobility through the base. It’s simple and absorbing. 

The story is basic but compelling, offering likeable characters who try to cope with challenges in a practical way. The writing builds a plausible world and situation without encumbering it with melodrama or complicated backstory. There is enough inherent drama in the basic scenario, and it was better that the game kept it simple. 

It’s neither very difficult (on normal) nor very lengthy, but it’s probably the right length to not outstay its welcome. I enjoyed the 3-6 hours I spent shivering through it.

37480804.review:
I love Near Death because it offers something different. It's a man vs. nature conflict. Weather is the only enemy, and it's a deadly one. Your plane crashes in the late Antarctic winter near an abandoned base on the continent. You have to get yourself to McMurdo Station where there is help, but it's a long way from where you are.

You run around the abandoned base, which has many different buildings on a large campus, looking for supplies that will help you. Meanwhile you try not to get lost in a nasty blizzard that gets worse with time. You're trying to avoid freezing to death so time outside or in unheated buildings is very limited. Oh, and it's pitch black outside, except for the snow. Your map is helpful, but you need to use your compass because the map, by design, does not give your "live" location. The wind builds and your trek between buildings slows to a crawl, you realize you were off on your map reading just a bit and are now lost (this rock wall isn't supposed to be here!!), you're shivering, the screen is getting blurry -- death is imminent. Good times!

You do low level crafting, making items that help combat the elements, but you rarely feel safe. I died several times on the normal difficulty. There are two levels of difficulty above that, for those who want more than a tourist experience. Ha!  Very enjoyable. The only thing I didn't like was that it ended. That said, the game doesn't overstay it's welcome. Highly recommended.

36585831.review:
Sadly, I can't recommend this game full price. For that there's just not enough here...of anything. The game revolves around a crashed pilot trying to escape death in Antarctica. You crash land hear an abandoned research base and have to gather supplies to survive and escape. To do that you can create some rudimentary items, like window flaps. You have a generator to generate warmth and you need to get the base back up operational. This just means going from one place of the base to another with the help of a rudimentary map and the actual way pointers in the game world. You can drop your own light markers as well if you craft them. All in all the game is "compelling", the music is great, the atmosphere desperate, as the snow storm gets worse and worse. However, since there's not really any challenge or gameplay here, apart from walking and searching stuff...and the game is barely 2 to 3 hours long, I'd say wait for a sale. I got it for under 3 bucks and I'm happy with the experience, but for 15? I'd wanna refund it...sorry, devs :/

It's also kinda nausea inducing and the FOV is never quite right. The crosshair (a big dot/square) can't be turned off for whatever reason, despite there being an option for it. It's extremely annoying and pointless, since you don't need it. Also, the game booted up in German, despite me choosing "English" when I was asked by the game. Now, I AM German, so that's no big deal, but for someone who speaks not a word of German this is kind of unacceptable, since changing the language back requires a bit of digging in the game's options menus.

Not sure what playing on higher difficulty means. Probably less supplies and faster body temperature drops. Graphics are ok by the way, but nothing to write home about. It's a better walking simulator.

36420318.review:
Jednym zdaniem: Arktyka może straszyć nawet bez potworów. Near Death to gra survivalowa, w której słowo survival naprawdę coś znaczy. Znalazłeś się sam w nocy, w opuszczonej bazie pośrodku zaśnieżonej Arktyki. I musisz przeżyć... Zabija Cię ciemność, wiatr i mróz... A twoimi sprzymierzeńcami są jedynie umierająca latarka, przenośny piecyk grzewczy na benzynę, orientacja w terenie i wola przeżycia - tylko te rzeczy mogą Cię utrzymać przy życiu. Ta gra to Coś, ale bez potwora z kosmosu. Tu straszy nas nieprzenikniona ciemność, bezlitosny wiatr i przerażający do kości chłód. Przez całą grę poruszamy się na krawędzi śmierci i tylko chwilami jesteśmy bezpieczni. Poczucie alienacji jest boleśnie prawdziwe. Ale to jest właśnie siła tej gry. Czujemy się jakbyśmy tam byli, a nie tylko w to grali.

Plusy: 

+ doskonale wręcz przemyślana mechanika rozgrywki
+ klimat z poczuciem alienacji jak nigdy do tej pory (jedynie Kholat mógłby się z tym równać)
+ dobra grafika i wzorowe ośwetlenie w ciemności doskonale budujące klimat gry 
+ niezwykle realistyczne efekty dźwiękowe, które budują chyba połowę klimatu gry
+ ponura, idealnie dobrana muzyka, która włącza się we właściwych miejscach
+ poczucie prawdziwej eksploracji (czujesz się trochę jak odkrywca, gdy coś znajdziesz) 
+ perfekcyjnie dopracowane efekty śmierci (gdy zamarzamy)
+ gra stanowi wyzwanie (jedynie poziom łatwy nie stanowi wielkiego wyzwania)
+ intuicyjny interfejs i dopracowane kompas i mapa (wygodniejsze niż w Kholat)
+ ciekawie zbudowana lokacja i teren, w którym budynki są mocno oddalone od siebie
+ można wyłączyć efekt trzęsienia kamery w wyniku silnego wiatru (czasami się to przydaje)
+ dobry system craftingu, w którym znajdowane przedmioty łączymy w przydatne rzeczy 
+ bardzo dobrze napisane dialogi (kontakt ze światem jedynie przez maszynę teletext) 
+ nawiązania (np. do Lśnienia Kubrika) i delikatna szczypta humoru
+ fajnie pomyślane zadania do zrobienia w grze, zeby móc przeżyć i uciec z bazy
+ Arktyka, jakiej nigdy do tej pory w grach nie było

Minusy: 

- wysoki poziom trudności (już Normal jest wyzwaniem)
- zakończenie mogłoby być trochę bardziej atrakcyjne

Komu polecam? / Komu odradzam?

+ polecam tym, którzy szukają gry survivalowej, która dawałaby autentyczne przeżycia
+ polecam fanom filmu Coś Carpentera, bo tu mamy bardzo podobny klimat
+ polecam graczom szukającym orygunalności i świeżości w grach oraz prawdziwych emocji 
- odradzam graczom, którzy w grze muszą sobie postrzelać, bo tu nie ma żadnej broni palnej
- odradzam graczom szukającym bardzo rozbudowanej fabuły, bo jej tu nie ma
- odradzam graczom lubiącym gry przyjemne i casualowe, bo Near Death to wyzwanie 

Rada 1: 

Chcesz zagrać naprawdę survivalową grę? To odrzuć wszystkie pseudosurvivale dla dzieciaków jak Rusty czy Arki  i wybierz sie na Arktykę, by zobaczyć czy przeżyjesz tylko jedną noc, gdy na termometrze jest prawie minus 100 stopni Celsjusza. Gry takie jak Rust czy Ark na wyrost używają nazwy survivalu jako gatunku. Zagranie w Near Death pokazuje jak tamte gry nie mają wiele wspólnego z prawdziwym przetrwaniem. Near Death można uznać za pierwszą w pełni survivalową grę z pespektywy FPP (bo de facto pierwszym survivalem była chyba znakomita This War of Mine, ale ona jest zrobiona z trochę innej perspektywy).

Near Death warto rozpocząć od poziomu Normal - nie próbujcie od razu iść na wyższe poziomy. Już na normalu jest dość trudno. A jeżeli będzie za często ginąć, to łatwo możecie też podczas gry obniżyć na poziom Easy, wtedy gra nie jest już tak bezwzględna. :)

Near Death mógłbym trochę porównać do Kholat - obie gry są wybitne, tylko że Kholat jest bardziej fabularny i bardziej horrrowy, a Near Death skupiony bardziej na prawdziwym survivalu.

이 게임의 컨텐츠는 서바이벌 입니다.
재미있게 하기 위해서는 몇 가지를 알고 있어야 되고 그에 대한 힌트도 많이 주지만 영어로 되어 해석할 시간이 필요하나 이 게임은 시간이 금인지라 모르고 지나치는 경우가 많습니다.

일단 이게임에 대해서 알아야 할 경우는 하기의 몇가지 입니다. (약간의 스포일러가 있을 수 있습니다)



1. 손난로는 내려 놓아야 몸을 녹일 수 있다.

2. 각 건물의 제너레이터와 전기 분배함을 고치면 전기가 들어옴과 동시에 방에 보온이 시작되어 난로를 쓰지 않아도 된다. (와이어 셋트가 필요하며 크래프팅으로 만들수 있다.)

3. 인벤토리의 재료들을 모아 크래프팅 할수 있는데 이 크래프팅 레시피는 돌아다니면서 찾아야 된다. (종이 문서다ㅣ크래프팅 중에 점퍼나 바지를 업그레이드 하면 추위에 좀 더 버틸 수 있다.

4. 이야기가 좀 진행 되면 밖의 날씨가 더 매서워지는데 바람의 역방향으로 갈려고 하면 거의 앞으로 가기 힘들다.
그럴때는 로프폴을 건물과 건물 사이에 연결해두면 강풍속에서도 빨리 갈 수 있다. 로프폴 없이는 가기 힘들기 때문에 중 후반부 중요 아이템이다. 또한 회수가 가능하다.

5. 라이트폴은 로프폴 근처에 꼽아두면 로프폴 찾기가 편하다.


위의 정도만 알면 그 다음부터는 거의 반복 과정이므로 그렇게 어렵지는 않습니다. (오히려 좀 지겨워 지는...)

서바이벌을 좋아하시는 분이시라면 그럭저럭 재미있게 할 수 있습니다. 생각보다 구성이 알차서 나쁘지는 않으나 분량이 많지는 않아 할인 시에 구매하시는 걸 추천드립니다.

36331047.review:
Pros and Cons, here we go!

Pros

1. Quite intense
2. Started on normal and you really do feel like you have to fight to survive.
3. The music at times knew how to take everything from intense to unsettling. Always quiet but disturbing
4. The price tag is really great.
5. Games like this continue to erode my confidence in huge titles and companies and now favor more Indie games(this being indie of course) 
6. The story line while simple made sense.

Cons

1. The game felt like it set you up perfectly for a second stage but instead ended. I don't mean it felt like a forced ending because it didn't. I'm just saying it easily could have gone further. DLC could very easily be added to this game and not feel forced in the least bit. DLC e.g. you have to make your way home of course but have your radar direct you to different outposts to gain much needed supplies. A different station, different requirements and so on.

2. Crappy batteries made sense and was spot on. Batteries sitting to long lose charge and therefore it easily stands to reason that you would chew through them quite quickly (as is the case) Kerosene did not make sense. It burns slowly so it made no sense that you burn through your fuel as fast as a drag racer goes through fuel. At the same time it's a semi con to the game because its understood that your fighting to gain body heat. If your fuel went on forever, half the strain of staying alive would be eliminated. That being the case I hold that con with a very light hand. 

And that's it on the cons. All I can say is I really wish they would add DLC and new areas so you have to fight your way back home.

Also, for there not being a single monster in the game the intensity, darkness and soundtrack really freaked me out at times and I wondered if something was going to step out of the shadows. Even when I knew that there were no other creatures in the game the feeling was always there. If anything had stepped out I would have shat myself. I know horror games that try to instill this level of fear and don't even come close to what they achieved here, maybe by accident.

36235086.review:
A rare find in the survival genre, Near Death is a tighly packaged experience that proves that you don't need monsters to make being trapped in the Antarctic horrifying. Playing a pilot whose plane went down over a decommissioned research station during polar night, the infeasability of rescue means you need to scour every inch of the station to put together what you need to make your own way to safety, all while the dark and cold do their level best to make you as miserable as possible.

This game is fairly short - I beat it in around four hours - but any longer would've just dragged on as the game sends you into a desperate survival situation at a fairly breakneck pace. Near Death presents a lonely, isolated setting where the air itself is such an oppressive, omnipresent threat that spending more than a minute outside of a sealed room will kill you, and such havens can feel few and far between as every other window is blown in and even a number of the walls have collapsed from the incessant siege of wind and snow.

Outside of the mere challenge of having to exist in such extreme conditions, the game is fairly straightforward and isn't much more than a series of fetch quests, but when the basic logistics of getting from point A to point B without freezing - or worse, getting lost when visiblity is next to zero - are so mounting such basic tasks are anything but trivial.

All in all I find very little to criticize about this game, and while the premise may not be for everyone, if what I've described here sounds like your cup of tea I suggest giving it a try.

36105054.review:
I bought this on sale, and I can say it was worth it.

Near Death has no zombies, vampires, plagues, robots, ninjas, trolls, elves, etc etc.  There are no enemies at all, and you have no weapons ether.  The whole story feels very realistic--I imagine that wandering around while stranded in Antarctica in 1982 would probably be very much as depicted in Near Death.  I kept wondering if there might be some jump scares, if I would find some creature lurking in the cold darkness of some room in the base.  Or, perhaps I would uncover pieces of some twisted military plot, some terrible research going on at the Sutro base.  But in fact, there's basically no one to interact with in the game, except some people you communicate with via a teletype (like a typewriter and a telephone together), hundreds of miles away, as they provide you guidance and warm wishes to help keep you, and the story, moving forward.  Apart from that, and the bit of humor that comes through at times in your communications, there is really only one main thing that drives the game forward--and that's the gameplay itself.

In a much larger and much broader game, perhaps a Mass Effect or Elder Scrolls or even Half Life, the gameplay of Near Death might make up a chapter or two.  But in this game, the creators have chosen to focus in on a few very specific gameplay elements.

The challenge is to survive the worst nature can throw at you: the wind, the snow, the darkness, and the freezing temperatures of Antarctica.  You do this with a few pieces of equipment, such as a flashlight, and later light rods you can plant in the snow; a heater you carry around to warm you up inside closed rooms; a blowtorch, to melt snow and ice and gain access to new rooms and supplies; and even your character's clothing is important, as you realize you can find ways to upgrade your clothing (and other items) to stay warmer for longer.  The game actually reminds me some of Neo Scavenger, another game in which it's important to manage the cold, stay warm with good clothes and scavenge stuff to stay alive--though Neo Scavenger also features food and sleep, and combat with sci-fi enemies.

If you manage to survive the earliest and most disorienting stages of the game, you will begin to get fetch quests, essentially, as you are sent off to the different parts of the base to retrieve pieces of equipment to aid your in your survival and escape.  Along the way you must properly manage your equipment and supplies, and avoid getting turned around too much when you're in the heavy wind and snow outside, and be certain you can get to heat sources in time.

Do that, and you should have a good chance of surviving and ultimately escaping Sutro.

If that sounds fun to you--a game where you're pitted against Mother Nature herself, rather than any kinds of enemies--you may find Near Death to be a wonderful little game, as I did.



Now, with all this said, there were some issues I had with Near Death.

Firstly, my laptop moved at a crawl much of the time while my character was outdoors.  Having some options to turn down the detail of the snow falling, and other such things, would have been nice.

I fell through a catwalk next to the power station--this was a clipping issue, not a piece of catwalk that broke (though there were a few catwalks that broke in scripted events).

And a few more gameplay-oriented annoyances:

It would have been nice to jump a little higher, and be able to climb up short objects.  There were several times where I would have just climbed up the side of a building, rather than being forced to find some way to go around.  And the duck-jump feature, by which I was able to gain access to certain areas, felt very clumsy compared to in Valve's FPS's, often requiring me to make several attempts.

The main character gets cold and dies too quickly in my view.  Even with all my clothes fully upgraded, I think it would only take one or two minutes to die.  Perhaps this was a deliberate decision to keep up a sense of urgency, but I think it could have been handled better.  Also consider that, in addition to dying too quickly from cold, I think the character also warms up too quickly once in the presence of heat.  You can go from being right on the point of death--wobbling around with your vision and hearing badly blurred from being too cold, literally ready to fall down dead--to being 100% OK and ready to go out into the cold once more, all in less than a minute, so long as you enter the presence of heat.  No frostbite, no numb limbs, almost no recovery time.  It's fun and scary to deal with, but it's also a kind of simplistic system that I think could do to be revamped.

Every single door in a room must be closed, and all of the broken windows must be sealed--no matter the size of the room or how closed off certain parts of it may seem--before your personal heater is able to warm you up.  I was bothered that I couldn't just move into a secluded corner, turn on the heater and get warm.

On a similar note, I kept on waiting for one of the generators to fail or run out of fuel, taking my best heat sources and forcing me to go on a hunt for more gasoline.  I was kind of disappointed that never happened.

I would have preferred if the locations, shapes, and sizes of the buildings, and their rooms, and the supplies available within them, were randomized.  Near Death kind of suffers from convenientitis.  Of course the very first building you find has the personal heater.  And of course that is the sole building that possesses the only personal heater, of the ~15 buildings in the game.  I think it's pretty clear that the game is meant to be played in a linear fashion, moving from one particular building to another in a particular order.  Early on I didn't realize that I was supposed to activate a generator, and instead ended up moving to another building.  Only after getting there and spending some time there did I realize I didn't have enough propane to stay warm with the personal heater.  I kept searching for propane but didn't find enough to last long.  Realizing I was probably going to freeze to death, I checked my inventory and objectives and such, and only then discovered that I had skipped an objective earlier, so I had to restart from the beginning.  Personally I think that randomizing building locations and supplies would really have added a whole new level of fun and difficulty to the game.



Overall, I enjoyed Near Death a lot.  It doesn't take too long to finish, even on the highest difficulty, which I've now completed as well.

***Minor spoiler alert***
Other than that, the only I have to say is that, on Normal difficulty anyway, the game ends with what is basically a sandbox mode.  After completing what was basically the last objective, the temperature suddenly went up from about -100 C to -5 C, and the wind and snow and darkness cleared.  It was the perfect time for this to happen, as I was up on top of the radar tower at a high elevation, and thus able to look down on all the other buildings below, able to see their lights and the green lights I'd placed around on the snow.  It was quite a beautiful moment, perhaps equally as memorable as all the chaos and peril of the game up to then.  Under those conditions, with virtually no fear of death, I happily went back to every building I could, exploring all around inside and out.
***End spoiler***

7.5/10  Near Death is nothing amazing, but it's certainly a lot of fun to play around with for a little while.

35935942.review:
Near Death is a very linear survival game. You have set goals with set locations. The only thing between you and survival is the harsh weather of Antartica. Through my own observations, it appears that the weather and temperature are dependant on which "checkpoint" you are at. When you first start, the temperature is well below 0 degrees Celcius. As you progress further in the game, the winds pick up and temperatures reach nearly -100 degress celcius. Im not saying that this is a bad thing, however, when the game is as short as it is (about 2 hours + if you understand what youre doing), RNG with the weather might be a nice touch. 

The game itself isn't very dependant on the map and compass (default button is M). You'll notice the compass in the top left hand corner, and the blue dial is the direction you are facing. While early game this is useful, towards the end, you should have rope poles and light poles set up so that you can run from building to building without much problem (rope poles allow you to sprint, even in the heavy winds).

Now, since this game is linear, there isnt much "re-playability". Yes, there are 4 different difficulties, but you are essentially doing the same thing over again, just on a different difficulty. (And a lot worse weather)

It is a wonderful game for what it is, and if you are looking for a nice survival game with a wonderful atmosphere, then Near Death is a good bet for you.

35536381.review:
Overall, I liked it... Despite the bugs, the game was enjoyable enough for me to keep playing. The game itself is a set of simple fetch quests. However, in order to sucessfully travel around the map and complete these fetch quests, you will need to craft various items and manage your resources. The difficulty slowly ramps up as you complete each task: visibility decreases and the wind becomes stronger, making travelling between locations increasingly difficult.

Bugs... there are a lot of bugs. You can jump-crouch through some of the windows (intact, non-broken windows), and you can also use/pickup items through windows. The collision with the terrain is sometimes glitchy as well. Worst of all is that whenever I'm within approximately 100 metres of the garage, my game starts intermittently freezing up for approximately 20 seconds at a time (nobody else seems to be experiencing this, so maybe it's just my setup?). I also experienced a total crash at one point. Regardless of the bugs, the game was still enjoyable.

Many people are complaining that the game is too short (about 3 hours), but I would argue the mechanics would get boring if the game was much longer. The game is bite-sized, but it's also quite tasty. That said, I don't think it's worth buying at its non-discounted price.

I went into this game knowing that it would be difficult, but I didn't ancitipated how absolutely [i] intense [/i] this game would be. 

Starting out knowing that my plan crashed, it was the typical start to most survival games, however you don't need to worry about food or water. Quite frankly, there isn't any sustenance in the game, and while that may break some of the immersion for some people, to me it only intensified and displayed just how urgent my situation was: I'm stranded in an abandoned facility, no food or water, electricity barely works, and all I have for communication is menial text between myself and someone at another station. Storms were difficult, and honestly terrifying at times, and I perished many times while thinkng I could make a trek when I couldn't. I had to navigate a map without a marker, making me [i] plan and prepare [/i] any treks that I did make. 

Over all, the game is fantastic. It was short, and took me just under three hours to complete with all but one of the blueprints found. Despite being on the shorter end of the spectrum, the game was beautifully crafted in that I was rather psyched out every time I hear the storm, every time I frantically tried to patch a window or repair circuitry. The game doesn't need monsters or animals of any kind: the true enemy is nature itself.

34625397.review: Near Death is an excellent game, in a minimalist sort of way. The only enemy is the environment: a freeze-to-death system which players of Cryostasis will find familiar, with the remarkably frightening addition that it is easy—and deadly—to lose one's way in the dark. The map is only that, and it's on the player to figure out where they are on it. This, combined with the darkness and whiteout conditions, makes placing guide ropes and beacon poles a very important (and actually rather enjoyable) mechanic. The crafting system works well, too. If I had one quibble, it would be that the final objective at the radar facility is not nearly so difficult as one might expect. (Or that the downed plane really should have been carrying survival gear.) Anyway, it's fun, it's atmospheric, and it's short enough that the limited mechanics don't get old.

That said, I felt tense when I was freezing, relief when I found a sealed room, and joy when I found a wiring box to fix.  Overall I greatly enjoyed the game, but would probably wait for a sale only because of the time to completion.  I hope at some point they consider making an expanded sequel.

[b]NEGATIVES[/b]

[b]FAZIT[/b]

Die verlassene Sutro-Forschungsstation in der Eiswüste der stockdunklen Antarktis ist Schauplatz von "Near Death" das Mitte 2016 erschien. Das ständige und vorrangige Ziel ist es erst einmal am Leben zu bleiben und nicht zu erfrieren. 
Tatsächlich ist Spielerlebnis sehr spannend und treibend. Zwar kann man sich frei bewegen, aber dennoch sind die Ziele in ihrer Reihenfolge recht linear, auch wenn man meist mehrere zugleich hat.

34355052.review:
This, is a very neat little game.

It's short, but there's not much else like it out there. Beat the game in just under 3 hours, so I would recommend grabbing in on sale somewhere in the $7-$10 range- you'll probably at most get double that hourage if you're looking to grab all the trophies.

The game does a great job of creating a constant sense of urgency, without being overwhelming brutal (on the normal difficulty), and there's a scene at the end of the game that's almost literal magic. It's one of those experiential things that is less about what occurs on paper, but how it impacts you directly as a player, how it makes YOU feel, and that alone makes me recommend this to ANYONE who enjoys good storytelling.

Tecnicamente un po' grezzo, questo breve survival riesce a compensare con delle buone meccaniche. In Near Death ci troveremo in una stazione di ricerca antartica, nel bel mezzo di una bufera di neve. Come se non bastasse, la stazione è abbandonata da tempo e nulla funziona come dovrebbe. Sta a noi cercare gli oggetti che possano esserci utili e creare i rattoppi necessari alla soppravvivenza ed alla fuga. Questo mentre teniamo d'occhio la nostra temperatura corporea, la quale non deve mai scendere sotto i livelli di allarme.

34121634.review:
Ce jeu comme son nom ne l'indique pas, nous mets dans la peau d'une héroïne s'étant cracher avec son hélicoptère dans une ancienne base en partie démolie au beau millieu de l'Antartique. Le but est simple? survivre, jusque là on pourrait dire que c'est du vus et du revus, mais ce qui est différent dans ce jeu, est que l'ennemie est présent partout, car il ne s'agit ni d'un monstre, ni d'un fou, non. L'ennemie de ce jeu n'est autres que le climat et le temps. Le vent gifle votres vissage et vous fait voir trouble voir même dégringoler des rares pont en bonne état, les habitations laisser à l'abandon ne vous laisse que quelques secondes de répit avant de devoir retourner dans cette enfer blanc et combattre l'hypotermie dans ce jeu où vôtre corps devient presque un obstacle à vôtre réussite. Au début du jeu on dirait que c'est toute l'Antartique qui veut nôtre mort. Entre le vent, la neige, le froid et le manque complet de visibiliter on à de plus en plus de mal à entrevoir une bonne fin.
Mais après avoir compris comment fonctionnait le temps et surtout avoir ranger mon égo d'humain dans le placard, j'ai enfin pus avancer, vouloir vaincre dans ce jeu est impossible, vouloir se croire meilleur que ce lieux inospitalier et c'est la mort qui vous fauchera.
Que dire de plus si ce n'est que les graphismes sont tout bonnement incroyable quand nous arrivons à la fin et que nous arrivons en haut des montagnes enneigées et verglacer, on ne peut que se surprendre à regarder presque hypnotiser les chemins que nous avons emprunter durant tous le jeux, nous parraissant encores si long, il y à peu, devenus maintenant simple chemin de montagne presque banaliser.

34101056.review:
Near Death es una aventura de supervivencia en primera persona… y hasta ahí puedo leer, el resto es cosa vuestra.


La ambientación es brutal, esa sensación de soledad ante la adversidad climatológica me ha encantado. Ese estado de tensión continua, esa fijación constante por llegar a nuestro objetivo, el entorno, las conversaciones … simplemente brutal. Y es que las conversaciones se sienten reales, son escuetas, directas, con algún toque de humor tonto debido a los nervios del momento. 

Vamos a morir, no lo dudes, y es una pena porque nos saca bastante de toda esa inmersión comentada recientemente, pero tened claro que es culpa nuestra y solo nuestra, por cabezones, porque las herramientas están ahí, solo hay que saber cuándo y dónde usarlas.

La banda sonora es muy simple, apenas dos canciones, si no me falla el oído. Se llega a hacer un poco repetitiva, y a veces sube a tonos tensos cuando no debería, pero bueno, no es nada que afecte demasiado a la experiencia de juego. Es más, probad a jugar sin ella y disfrutad del sonido de las tormentas.


Siento ser tan abstracto, pero siendo un título tan corto, apenas cuatro o cinco horas, y basando este análisis únicamente en esa ambientación que engloba al juego y que me ha sulibellado, no quiero contar nada del argumento a pesar de ser este muy simple.

Pd: disfrutad de las vistas finales, son una maravilla.


Espero que os haya sido útil.
Un saludo!

33999013.review:
Near Death is a clear recommendation for people that like story-based games with a dense atmosphere. This game focusses on the absolute essentials of surviving - nature and your character. No gimicks, no mosters, nothing supernatural, just a single person trying to survive in a deserted antarctic base.

It has to be noted that Near Death is very short (2,5 hrs. or less, if you speedrun) and does not reward exploring in any way. If you are looking for open world survival and base building, you are in the wrong place. That however is not a downside at all, as making it any longer or allowing more opportunities to derail from the given path would most likely have weakened the overall experience. And, due to its atmosphere and the four difficulty levels, it however still has some replayability in it.

5 Stars out of 5 - if Steam would allow for a rating other than thumbs up!

33937087.review:
Near Death is, for all intents and purposes, a survival game. Unlike the sandbox survival titles that are usually associated with "survival", however, this game is story-driven, hand crafted with little to no random elements and, while it doesn't avoid the concept of "crafting", it has more in common with the permanent upgrades you'd see in a metroidvania here than collecting random junk to created another random junk. In fact, despite one open map, the game is very much linear.

Which is, probably, the biggest gripe I have with it. With the way the story progresses and the map is set up, I'm genuinely surprised the developers locked down exploration as much as they did with outright not giving you tools necessary to progress before they want you to by just making them unpickable. Which, unlike other key stuff the character would really have no reason to pick up until it becomes important, looks extremely stupid and also introduces the ugly "okay, now what" problem, when you have explored a location before you had to and have no clue that now you have to go back to it again.

All that said, this is quite a unique and amazing experience with you stumbling in extreme conditions from building to building, from room to room, searching for a warm place and something helpful to scavenge. To fix the rooms, to make navigation between buildings easier. It's a unique concept, which, while looking less beautiful and impressive as in Cryostasis, works really well and shows how exploration games can be made and how many themes, locales and ideas are still left unexplored for truly engaging experience. I would highly recommend checking Near Death for while it is deeply flawed, it is also very fun. Also, a great game to play during hot summer.

It was nice to have a game without jump scares and monsters. There's something [word not found, vocabulary failing me] about playing, or being, in isolation.

As far as cons, the game is a string of fetch quests/go where you're told (though there's always opportunity to die while fetching.) So if that's not what you want, I wouldn't spend money on it. It's also is a fairly short play. Perhaps hard difficulty somehow extends the length of play, but I can't imagine it would be by much.

33667709.review:
Near Death, a game about surviving alone in Antarctica after your plane crashes near an abandoned research facility, is a treat of smart and unique game design.  It's a short but sweet experience, with a simple premise elevated by its attention to detail and valuable sense of progression.  

You start things off out in the open, facing down the chill and inky darkness of the derelict facility with only a flashlight to help peer through the night and a kerosene lantern for warmth.  The flashlight has limited life unless supplied with fresh batteries, and the lantern will warm you in sealed spaces, but only when fueled with vital kerosene; both of which can be found in precious scarcity throughout the facility.  Some parts of the facility interior have busted windows letting in the cold or doors held open by the wind which need to be patched up and shut respectively.  This is where some light crafting comes into play as the remains of canvases and duct tape allow for makeshift seals, letting you break out your lantern to ward off death once a room is closed off from the elements.  These mechanics never feel cumbersome though, as progress is saved regularly and you learn to think in small goals; taking baby steps to ensure survival rather than making a mad dash from one end of the map to the other, freezing to death in the process.  Immersion is a big part of the experience as well, as the only indicators that you're getting too cold or have fully warmed up is through convincing voice acting; shivering in the cold growing more and more panicked or a quick "much better" after huddling with your lantern.

The key to survival then, is braving the outdoors in hopes of making it alive to the next sealed facility space to warm up and look for supplies, then continuing on to the next major goal.  It's easy to get disoriented when out in the elements however, as the few, sparse lights of the barely functioning facility act as dim beacons in the dark and the wind rages against your progress.  It very accurately captures the feeling of struggling to find safety as your head bobs violently, exhausting yourself before barely reaching respite.  Yet narrowly escaping death and warming yourself in a new space, filled with supplies, is a feeling of pure joy and quickly becomes a highlight of the game.  It never feels unfair when you die, but rather, an error in calculation.  Perhaps you tried to go too far in a single trek and had the misfortune of coming upon a door that's been frozen shut with no more time to look elsewhere before you freeze.  You quickly learn from these mistakes, and learn the facility bit by bit, so you reload your last save and try to be smarter next time.

In short time, you come into contact with help via a teletype 2-way messaging system, and from there are given some hope for rescue and instructions as to how to survive long enough to be saved and bring some of the facility back online.  Turning a part of the facility from a barren deathtrap into a self-heating haven is elating, and offers a welcome break from the survival aspects of the game; allowing you to save on batteries and kerosene.  Rescue is still a long ways off however thanks to the turbulent weather, so basking in your small victory must give way to soldiering on and securing more long-term means of survival.  It keeps you engaged with realistic survival objectives to achieve, and rewards you for your efforts in tangible and surprising ways.

Ultimately, Near Death sets out to do one thing right, and it accomplishes it in spades.  Simulating a no-frills survival experience in a lonely, unforgiving place.  There's no monster besides nature itself, no magic to learn or shelters to construct from wood and earth, just you, some hobbled-together necessities of life, and the punishing cold and darkness.  It feels simple, but intuitive and engaging because of it.  It doesn't need to be more, and what it is is done with exceptional thought and care.  Near Death is a hidden gem in the survival genre, and it frames its own identity with a well-earned confidence.

33467744.review:
[b]Briefly: An intense survival story game surprises with its simplicity and shows that it doesn't need a monster to maintain suspension.[/b]

There was a sharp contrast with the weather in-game and IRL when I first played [i]Near Death[/i]: I mean, in the middle of the Finnish summer, short as it is, I was [i]hot[/i] while in-game I was freezing at below 80 degrees C temperatures and fighting for my life.

[i]Near Death[/i] is a convoluted experience. It's a survival story about not freezing to death. It's also got simple crafting mechanics and some exploration aspects.

However, the emphasis is really on the story and the desperate atmosphere. The limited resources demand action and constantly pushing forward. It is [i]not a horror game[/i] despite its gloomy looks and rather obvious sources of inspiration, although the situation presented would be considered horrendous in most scales. Yet the atmosphere is intense and keeps you on your toes.

[h1]Introduction: The fall[/h1]

Story begins as you crash-land to Antarctica in the middle of the (polar) night. Alone in the dark, the only spark of hope is the nearby research station. Alas, it is abandoned. You have to get out of here before lack of heat, hunger and shear exhaustion bring you down!

The story is simple, yet powerful. You set out to gather various resources and find shelter. Not only are the supplies extremely limited, there's also what would be considered the blizzard of the century coming up if it were experienced way up here in the squishy latitudes. Your only solace: a contact in another station. But the news are always bad.

[h1]So cold[/h1]

Atmosphere in [i]Near Death[/i] is immense: darkness engulfs the landscape and only dim storm lights lead the way to a shelter. And the storm is getting stronger.

Fairly intuitive, you will die of hypothermia if you stay too long in the cold. A main game resource is heat and how to retain it long enough to complete all your tasks. Fortunately you've got a heater that can be used in-doors, as long as the room is sealed.

However, heater takes fuel. Your meagre flash-light requires batteries and it keeps running out. Good thing the protagonist has a knack for tinkering and can craft all kinds of nifty tools and upgrades. No silly combining is required, you just click on the craftable item in the inventory and she creates it if there's enough parts at hand.

The constant rush forward is relaxed only after you get the power up and may think about your slim options.

[h1]Short but intensive[/h1]

The whole game only takes a few hours to complete but it is intense. There are four difficulty options, from [i]easy[/i] to [i]Condition 1[/i], the latter a reference to the classification of the most extreme weather conditions on Antarctica. Difficulty affects the amount of resources, the resilience of the protagonist and the duration of the flashlight batteries/heater fuel.

Almost bug-free, only once I got stuck in some snow bank and promptly died of cold. I experienced no crashes during any of my playthroughs. I played it once on Normal (I took ~4 hours) before playing it through thrice on Condition 1 (~2 hours per new game).

The experience was so cool (pardon the pun) that I feel [i]Near Death[/i] has great re-playability (hence my extra playthroughs), even after grabbing all the achievements. I feel that a great part of the reason was the intense ending that only feels stronger at higher difficulties.

The game is unfortunately quite short so maybe the €15 ask-price is a bit steep, but on a sale, I think it's well worth at least €10. It surely made me appreciate our double-paned windows in a new light.

33173523.review:
Very impressed with this game! Not your typical survival game, as it's not open ended, has a storyline, and is rather short, but a masterpiece nonetheless. I'll try to keep this review spoiler free, as giving away details will ruin the experience.

[h1]Premise:[/h1]

You play as a pilot who's plane crashes in Antartica. Heading for a nearby research outpost, you discover it abandoned, and must find a way to survive and escape.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]

Graphics aren't top of the line, but are decent enough. The game makes liberal use of the snow effects, using it to obscure far away distances, but does so in a realistic manner. Most of the interiors were fairly generic, but given that it's supposed to be an Antartic rescearch facility, it didn't need to be unique, in my opinion. Exteriors were better, but that may be because I didn't take too much time to examine them, as you're almost never safe outside, and can rarely see very far in front of you.

Lighting was well done, not too bright not too dark, enough to make me have to make use of my flashlight, but not so much to where I was leaving it on all the time.

The game offers a few filters in the options, which I thought was a nice touch, however, I don't recommend them for your first playthrough. It's hard enough to get your bearings in the storm without extra filters.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]

One of the high points of the game. From the foreboding music, to the near constant howl of the wind, to every creaking metal door you open, even the crunch of snow as you walk, the sound design of this game did an amazing job of setting the mood. There wasn't much in the way of voice acting, but the little there was sounded realistic and well placed. The deep gasps of warm air after trudging through the snow and nearly freezing to death are incredibly satsfying to hear.

[h1]Story:[/h1]

The story wasn't deep, but served it purpose of driving the game foward. It consists of your character's correspondence with home base, which is where you get your objectives and information on where to find suppiles. The teletype machines, reminicent of old spy movies, made the choice of minimal voice acting interesting. Still, I felt connected to the character. Her sarcastic wit, to her reassuring herself she can make it, and even her sighs of relief when she finally gets warm, really helped put me in her shoes- er, snow boots.

[h1]Controls:[/h1]

Controls were simple and intuitive, consisting of WASD keys for movement, C to crouch, space to jump,  1-5 for selecting items and left clicking to interact or use your equipped item. The game did a good job of making me feel like I was stumbling and having trouble walkng in a straight line during strong winds, afraid that I wasn't heading in the direction I thought I was, just like a real storm.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

Another high point of the game, arguably the best point. Sound and graphical design did a good job of immersing me in this game, and gameplay mechanics did a good job of keeping me there.

The heat/cold system was well done, rather than giving you a temperature gauge, gave you audible cues from your character to let you know when it was time to stop and get warm and if you were warm enough to continue. I usualy see games like this trying to add monsters or creatures creeping around in the shadows trying to kill you, instead this game decided to make nature itself the antagonist of the story. As the game goes on, the storm gets stronger, and you start to wonder if you're going to make it.

The crafting system was simple, but interesting. Supplies were just sparse enough to force you to manage your inventory carefully, lest you run out of something important like kerosene for your portable heater or batteries for your flashlight. New recipes were unlocked by finding folders stamped with the research facility logo, or a couple of times by finding a new item. There were even a few upgrades for your gear, such as a manual that details how to make your parka warmer so you can last longer in the cold.

[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]

This game had me so sucked in that even though it was 70 degrees in my house, I was getting chills, and when I paused to take my dogs out, I was fully expecting a blast of cold air to hit me when I opened the back door. At points, I'd recieve another objective and would just stop and stare at the door for a few seconds, mentally preparing myself for the storm raging outside. The sense of dread that you might not make it to the next safe space to get warm hangs over you right up until the end. The thought of "Did I get everything?" that crosses your mind right before you step out into the snow to trek to the next building, because you REALLY don't want to have to come back because you missed something. The thoughts of, "Will I make it?""Should I use my meager supplies now or save them?""Oh God, I hope the next building is close" all cross your mind as you focus on trying to stay alive, and trying to escape.

This was probably one of my favorite purchases in a long time, and my only regret is I waited so long to pick it up.

Cold, dark, tense, and fun as heck! There are no jump scares and there are no monsters. Just our protagonist and the elements. An intensely compact game that can be finished within a few hours at most, but packs an incredible amount of tension and palpable fear of the cold. The immense struggle to compare this to more famous survival games is hard to let go, but I'll instead wish to point out that there is no amount lacking in conveying the unforgiving nature of being alone in the cold hoping to just make it to the next building to warm up.

The environmental detail is sparse - but then again this is a land of ice and snow. The game succintly develops a sense of tension as the weather whips up and the cold drops down further and further around you. There is an amazing soundtrack that creates an oppressive feeling in your ears when you wander into the darkness. It's a pulsing sound like that of a heartbeat. Which leaves you feeling paranoid, alone, and as if something is hunting you. The Artic has thrilled the minds of explorers and scientists since it was first recorded. And has taken it's fair share of lives of the brave, unfortunate, and unlucky. When the very elements of the land are so hostile and dangerous to people that is the greatest threat and it's fascinating that this game was able to re-create this feeling. 

I greatly enjoyed this game and recommend it to anyone who wants a short but great game. I highly recommend playing this in the dark with headphones. I hope the developers of this game will create something akin to it in the near future with the same nuanced fear inducing feeling.

Better dress up warm.

33017573.review:
"In the face of overwhelming odds, I'm left with only one option. I'm going to have to science the s**t out of this."

I've described Near Death to some people as an excellent video game adaptation of The Martian; a story of a scientist alone in an incredibly lethal environment, fighting against all odds and incredibly poor luck to stay alive. It's definitely scary, in fact many other readers have tagged it as a Horror Game. But for once, it's really really cool to have a horror game in which camp-enthusiasts are not encouraged to laugh in jest at the weirdness of the tentacle-faced monsters you face. Near Death's only opponent is the cold - temperatures below 100 degrees celcius, and winds that have the power to turn a sprint into a 1-foot-per-second crawl.

Progress in the game involves a long series of fetch quests through the facility's many buildings. Any room without a total vacuum seal against the outside is freezing cold, meaning that sometimes your progress through buildings may have to be taken in steps, and some rooms have such large breaches that you'll need to rush your looting to avoid freezing.

The game is actually quite brutal just in the challenge of getting between buildings. Mercifully, you have a compass, but even with that, it's very easy to lose your bearings in such total darkness, and even high winds reducing your speed. You can redeem yourself by planning ahead and crafting light / rope poles to make return trips easier, but even these can go wrong. More than once I made a stupendous trek through the snow, found the building, got inside, only to find out that through my desperate run, I ended up at the wrong building (or, even, the back door of the building I had left from).

Sometimes, I thought "[b]F*** it[/b]. The doors here are frozen over?? This turnout feels unfair. I want to give up. Kill me so I can go back to my last quicksave." But...something about the theming of the situation made me reconsider. I thought about moments in The Martian where Mark exhibits just about the same feelings. It made me want to turn those situations around. I knew I wouldn't reach the building I was aiming for, but I kept going, kept trying to recover my goals, because a person in this real situation wouldn't get a second chance. I certainly did die a few times, even playing on Easy Mode ([i]I first tried Hard Mode, but found myself rushing so much to get warm / not waste kerosene I actually missed an important tutorial message - Easy still gave me much of the intended feel of the game[/i])

Near Death is very short, so buy it if you tend to not have enough spare time to finish off most games in your Steam backlog, since you could very likely easily binge through it in one gaming session. I felt like it was unique enough and well-executed enough to be worth my time either way.

32873342.review:
The words ‘indie survival game’ might rightly encourage a degree of nausea in many of Steam’s users, after the horrific flood of terrible titles allowed onto the marketplace through Greenlight and the like poisoned the well for so many genuinely competent works. But every once in a while you find that diamond in the rough that bucks the trend and actually manages to deliver everything that indie games promise – a unique experience that doesn’t have the market clout necessary to see it given attention or funding from a major studio, often an experimental or left-of-centre concept, perhaps something personal, or simply something with a single, focused ambition. 

Near Death is absolutely that diamond. Built with a loving nod to John Carpenter’s The Thing, you play a pilot and engineer whose plane is downed in a storm whilst on-route to her base in Antarctica. You crash-land near a decommissioned station, and with the temperature plummeting and visibility decreasing by the minute, you must find your way to the nearest building and contact your colleague via teletype, who gives you what little assistance he can. From then on, the situation becomes more and more bleak as you find supplies and reactivate the power to the various parts of the station, braving the storm to venture between different buildings and build your plan of escape. Spending any more than half a minute outside will kill you, and your movement and vision is impeded as you freeze to death. You aren’t much safer indoors, as rooms with broken windows or walls offer no respite from the cold, and you have nothing to warm you but a small portable heater that will only work in sealed rooms. You can improve certain items such as your torch and parka, and these will make survival marginally more likely, but despite my initial overestimation of my abilities, you can and will get lost outside if you’re not careful, which will spell certain death under most circumstances.

The game saves frequently, thankfully, so even if you die, it won’t likely set you back very far, but there is a certain degree of anxiety that hits every time you have to trek to another building, especially as the game progresses and the storm gets worse. The wind picks up and can make walking almost impossible unless you have fashioned or manage to find or build a rope line, which mitigates the movement penalty of high winds, and gives you a trail to follow to the nearest building. These are few and far between, and absolutely necessary in the later stages of the game, and there’s no worse feeling than knowing you’ve left underprepared when the wind is stopping you from moving forward, and you’re too cold and tired to move back, and you just know that you’ve doomed yourself. 

The games visual assets are simple, but suitable. We’re not looking at the Unreal 4 engine here, but there’s enough of a degree of detail in the environments to give an immediate feeling of familiarity to anyone that’s…y’know…been to a science base in the Antarctic, and the lighting effects are extremely well-implemented; darkness feels suffocating, the buildings are creepy in their dark, unexplored corners, and the eerie green pulsing glow of light poles will fill you with dread as they appear and disappear from view. Similarly, the script is simple but tight, and the small amount of voice acting on hand is believable and helps immerse you in the world. As your character starts shivering uncontrollably and your movement lurches and slows, you might feel a genuine chill within yourself as you know that you’re killing her. But in that way, every light in the distance becomes a beacon of hope, and closing the door on a sealed room leaves you with a palpable sense of relief. 

Near Death is not an epic affair, but in a market that has been flooded with games that oversaturate themselves with gimmicks and vast but empty worlds, it’s always refreshing to come across a game that performs a single premise very, very well. And Near Death absolutely nails it. I recall that when pondering whether or not to buy this game I was unsure from the reviews as to whether it was just a ‘walking simulator’ or something similar, but I can assure you that it’s not. It is a survival game, and a bit of an adventure, and the degree to which you scavenge and prepare ahead of venturing into the cold, especially in the later game, will absolutely make the difference between life and death. As your supplies dwindle (maybe you’ve been a bit too frivolous with your flashlight or your heater), you will find yourself praying to find a single item in one of the desks or lockers, and if you can’t, you will steel yourself to make do and hope for the best. Or perhaps you’ll do as I did and run out of the equipment to make rope poles, be forced to venture blind into the height of the storm and pray you make it to the nearest building, get disorientated, nearly die, and make it inside just in time to save yourself from the brink, all in order to retrieve and reuse some poles from elsewhere. This game is harrowing, and after I was finished I felt like I watched a great survival movie. It’s a class act, and I frankly can’t believe I haven’t heard of it before.

32751264.review:
Near Death is a survival sandbox indie title similar to The Long Dark or Stranded Deep. It is a bare-bones, but delightful experience overall.

The game is set in 1980's Antarctica, and it is all about surviving cold temperatures. The player is placed in the boots of an unnamed female pilot who crashes (because helicopters in video games) and has to survive in an abandoned base.

The only real mechanic to worry about is body heat. The player gets colder and colder until she dies, and can only warm up by sealing the doors and using a portable heater (or turning the generators on.) Hazards include storms, broken windows, pitch black conditions, and other fun things. 

The game is easy to get a hold of, looks very nice, and is very well polished. There were a few clipping issues where I phased through closing doors, but ultimately, nothing was confusing, and the game's two characters (Miss Pilot and a man she talks to on what passes for 1980's texting) have loads of charm. 

If you're into survival games, pick this up. It's easy to play and understand. Fairly short (I beat it in an afternoon). 

Survive out there.

32709093.review:
Let's get this out of the way.  Near Death is an indie game and it is short.  It is *very* short.  I took my time, wandered about at the end, reloaded the ending a few times, toyed around Sutro station after campaign end and sat back and soaked in the menu imagery/soundtrack before I uninstalled.  The game is probably closer to 2 hours in length than 3.  

I still recommend it.

Why?  The engine runs well, the game experienced minimal glitching during the three hours I played it.  The game was serviceably attractive and brutally atmospheric.  It's not often that you encounter a survival horror title that doesn't revolve around aliens, or zombies, or monsters, or evil people.  Near Death pits one determined woman against the most dangerous and inhospitable place on Earth: night-cloaked, winter-ridden Antarctica.  The game has minor crafting, some minimal puzzling and solemly ominous script.  However, the star of the game is the intense environments, coupled with an almost frenetic need to regulate your body warmth.

Jaunts, however temporary, between structures in Sutro station become an all-out fight for survival.  Visibility declines.  Temperatures plummet and the wind gusts can easily move you/point you in different directions.  It is exceptionally easy to get lost or pointed in the wrong direction, where a short trek into the snowy wilderness means certain death.  Players must carefully ration batteries, kerosene and other equipment for maximum efficiency.  Light/rope poles become your greatest friends when caught outside during a blizzard.

I initially started the game on basic Easy mode to finish it one quick go-through (I didn't think dying would support the premise of the game).  However, after finishing the game in about an hour and 45 minutes with no deaths, I can honestly recommend that Normal difficulty would probably be a better fit for most.  With careful gameplay, deaths can still be avoided and the game would probably lengthen to 2 hours +.  The game provides a satisfying, if not exactly flamboyant ending and the Antarctic landscape offers a glorious surprise while you descend from your final fetch quest/mission.

The game isn't exceptionally complex.  It lacks a wide array of features.  It doesn't have a hyper advanced graphics engine or massive multiplayer longevity.  What the game *does* have are atmosphere and tension in spades.  You will struggle to keep cool as you stumble towards your destination, as your labored breathing and chilled feet continue to plod slowly forward in knife-like blizzard winds.  You will care for the protagonist and most of all, you will appreciate the opportunity to play a game where your task isn't to kill, maim or destroy but, instead to survive against mother nature, in the face of overwhelming odds.

Near Death can be had on sale for five dollars and for a 3 hour jaunt unlike anything you've likely ever experienced before...it's worth it.

Recommended. 

7/10.

31508090.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review [/h1]

Near Death is the next game from the developers of The Novelist, developed and published by Orthogonal Games

Buy this game on sale if you can, but only buy it for the full 15 EUR if you want to support the developers. This is a good game. It was a very immersive, very tense, and harrowing journey into the Antarctic wasteland

Near Death takes homage from John Carpenter's The Thing, however, there aren't any enemies in this game, aside from the frigid weather of Antarctica in the middle of a raging blizzard

The survival aspect in this game is really something. When you're outside for too long, and you begin to succumb to the -100C kind of cold, you genuinely feel relieved when you make it to a spot to warm up

You have to use your supplies wisely and always make sure you keep warm

This game does not hold your hand. There are no quest markers. All you get is a map, and it doesn't even show you where you are on the map

You have to use common sense to navigate your way through the blizzard to the many different buildings of the abandoned Sutro Station, which has fallen into disrepair. You need to place light posts in the ground to mark paths to different buildings

You need to make a rope trail between buildings so you don't get staggered by the strong, freezing winds. You need to make use of the crafting system by collecting supplies wherever you can in order to survive

Stay warm. Collect supplies. Jury rig said supplies into things you can actually make use of. Just keep going, and try to survive

If you want a deep story, look somewhere else. If you want a ton of content, look somewhere else. If you're looking to slay monsters and collect epic loot, look somewhere else. But if you're looking for a fun, challenging, and actually immersive survival experience, then this might be the game for you

I can honestly see myself playing it again on harder difficulties so I can get the rest of the achievements from the game and also because it's fun!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

31485846.review:
I really like the premise; I think it can be improved, but I stopped playing this game because it wasn’t fun for me. I played for about 5 hours on Normal. I paid $7 for the game.

The core mechanics are: 
1) as you are exposed to the elements, you begin to die, so you must constantly search for shelter; 
2) the storm both disrupts visibility and impedes movement – setting rope-lines improves movement; 
3) resources are scarce, you will constantly consume them, so you must constantly scavenge.

How this works well: 
There’s only one thing that will kill you; getting lost in the storm. Consequently, you have to be cautious in your exploration, especially when you’re going to have to carry something heavy from point A -> B. You will generally have just enough resources to do what you need to do and then move on. 

How this works poorly: 
1) Artificial scarcity: your batteries run out in about two minutes of flashlight use, 
2) Fixed Objective Order: you need to complete areas in an exact order, objective items will not be highlighted absent that. For instance, I cannot infer the need to pick up area maps or survival equipment until after receiving those instructions.  
3) Constant fetch it quests that require encumbered movement in low visibility, movement impaired conditions – this feels like padding designed to stretch the game out.
4) Jumping requirements in windy conditions, where failure is close enough to death that a quicksave/quickload style is the only viable alternative.

Other comments:
The map doesn’t have nearly enough details (i.e. which pods are where), nor does it allow notation of any kind; furthermore, the compass is only accessible from the map, requiring the player to constantly toggle. Given that navigation is core to this game, and visibility is highly limited, this is a cardinal sin. WE SHOULD BE ABLE TO EQUIP THE COMPASS, if it’s not always visible by default. 

Closing:
I appreciate what the devs tried to do here, and I won’t hit them with a negative review. That said, I think there are some real problems with the game, and I hope the devs can sort some of them out. I have a little difficulty with spatial orientation, so I respect that aspects which were deal breakers for me might not be for other players.

Buy this game on sale if you can, but buy it for the full $15 if you want to support the developers.  This is a good game.  It was a very immersive, very tense, and harrowing journey into the Antarctic wasteland.  I paid full price for the game and it took me about 5 hours to beat it.

Many others might say that a game that only lasts for 5 hours isn't worth $15, but I disagree.  To me, it seems that PC gamers feel so entitled to get a ton of content from any game that costs more than $5.  I am not one of those people.  I am happy to spend $15 on a good game and show my support for future releases from Orthogonal Games.  I had never heard of them before, but they're definitely on my radar now.

Now let's get past the price and into the game itself.

There aren't any enemies in this game, aside from the frigid weather of Antarctica in the middle of a raging blizzard.  The survival aspect in this game is really something.  When you're outside for too long, and you begin to succumb to the -100 degrees celsius kind of cold, you genuinely feel relieved when you make it to a spot to warm up.  You have to use your supplies wisely and always make sure you keep warm.

This game does not hold your hand.  There are no quest markers.  All you get is a map, and it doesn't even show you where you are on the map.  You have to use common sense to navigate your way through the blizzard to the many different buildings of the abandoned Sutro Station, which has fallen into disrepair.  You need to place light posts in the ground to mark paths to different buildings.  You need to make a rope trail between buildings so you don't get staggered by the strong, freezing winds.  You need to make use of the crafting system by collecting supplies wherever you can in order to survive.

This is a game about survival, through and through.  If Orthogonal Game were going for realism, they achieved that goal in spades.  Stay warm.  Collect supplies.  Jury rig said supplies into things you can actually make use of.  Just keep going, and try to survive.

If you want a deep story, look somewhere else.  If you want a ton of content, look somewhere else.  If you're looking to slay monsters and collect epic loot, look somewhere else.  But if you're looking for a fun, challenging, and actually immersive survival experience, then this might be the game for you.  I can honestly see myself playing it again on harder difficulties so I can get the rest of the achievements from the game.  And also because it's fun.

30055312.review:
Спорный вопрос: стоит ли игра своих денег? И всё-таки я отвечу что да. Near Death проходится за пару часов, даже если вы любитель полного проникновения в игру, который любит всё читать, слушать, выполнять дополнительные задания и тому подобное. Ещё это инди, которую создавали малоизвестные разрабы с маленьким (очень) запасом средств. НО, тем не менее видно что они очень старались. Команда Orthogonal Games выглядит как очень талантливый художник, у которого просто не хватает красок на палитре. Вы уже догадываетесь что игра атмосферная? Я это отрицаю, она не просто атмосферная, она просто берёт и суёт в шкуру главной героини, она наиатмосфернийшая! Даже играя в тепле я почти чувствовал эту мощную пургу, эти ноги стрянущие в глубоких сугробах и темноту, что давила со всех сторон... 
Расскажу кратко и без спойлеров о сюжете. Он вряд ли имеет какой-то глубокий смысл, типа "вот на что способен человек!" или "жизнь - она штука нелёгкая!", игра просто повествует о типичной ситуации, когда человек попадает в сложные экстримальные условия. И хоть она линейная (это ещё как посмотреть), всё же её смысл - выжить. Крушение самолёта, ночь, Антарктика, заброшенная полярная станция, истинное одиночество и градус под -80°. Концовку ожидал честно говоря другую... она оказалась какой-то недосказанной что-ли.
Геймплей: у вас есть список задач, ограниченный инвентарь, "мастерская" с незамысловатым крафтом и, карта этой самой станции. По продвижению в сюжете будут открываться новые задания, в том числе и дополнительные необязательные. Все они между собой похожи: бегать мо метели из блока в блок, брать от туда что-то/ чинить-включать, обязательно греться и связываться по телетайпу со своими спасителями из "Мак-Мердо". Постепенно по ходу прохождения будет открываться новое снаряжение и новые модификации. Для выживания обязательно придётся собирать все ресурсы, главные из них будут батарейки для фонаря и керосин для обогревателя (и паяльника).
Оптимизация могла быть и получше для такой простой графики, но я отнёсся с пониманием. Кстати что ещё интересно, в настройках "видео" можно выставить забавные эффекты, которые позволят видеть происходящее в стиле ретро, нарисованной картине или телевизоре (а "почтовый ящик" вообще уберёт всё освещение). Саундтрек очень нагнетающий, за что поставлю жирный плюс. 
Вывод: Near Death за эти 5 часов с передышкой принесла мне достаточно эмоций, чтобы я рекомендовал вам эту игру (по скидке тем более!). Те чувства, когда после сильного мороза заходишь в тёплый бар с бильярдом, или когда замёрзшими пальцами строчишь текст своему приятелю в надежде что он наконец ответит "всё хорошо, ты спасена", бесценны.

Story: Mager. Sie wird über einen Telegraphen vermittelt. Dialogoptionen gibt es nicht. Nach einer Bruchlandung in der Arktis, findet die Pilotin eine verlassene Station vor und bastelt sich ein Fluchtgefährt, um zurück zu ihrer Basis zu gelangen.

FAZIT: Bei Sale-Angebot bedingt empfehlenswert, wenn man einige Stunden mit Suchen und Sammeln verbringen möchte. Mehr sollte man nicht erwarten. Der volle Preis ist für die Kürze doch etwas zu hoch angesetzt, für mein Empfinden. Daher ein Daumen runter.

[h1]ТУТ ХОЛОДНО И Я ЧЁРТ ЗНАЕТ ГДЕ! [/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=865178456
Откопал тут едва замеченный пользователями – Near Death. Довольно простая игра, по сути квест от первого лица, с некоторыми интересными особенностями. Весьма печально, но хоррора тут не оказалось вовсе, это полностью приключенческая игра в антураже жуткого холода. Зато в плане отчуждения и ощущения себя через знает где - работает отлично. Мы в роли девушки-пилота застряли в заснеженных льдах и пытаемся выбраться. Хоть для прохождения хватит 3-4 часа и все действия не требуют особых усилий, починить генератор или найти нужную вещь. То вот найти или дойти до выполнения этих целей - самое сложное.  Дело в том, что на улице лютый мороз и пребывание на нём 2-3 минуты моментально загонят вас в могилу. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=865178480
Особенно тяжело в начале, когда совершенно нет ресурсов, согреваться нужно только переносным обогревателем на керосине. Лёгкий крафт позволяет заклеивать разбитые окна что бы можно было согреться, ремонтировать проводку и даже создать пару утеплённых вещей. На улице постоянная метель и дальше пары метров абсолютно ничего не видно. Когда находишь карту, думаешь ну всё, теперь легкотня. А потом признаёшь, что жестоко ошибался, когда после, заблудился между двумя зданиями расстояние между которых всего 200-300 метров. Тут удивляешься насколько чувствуешь будто происходит всё с тобой. Это чуть ли не единственная игра такого рода, где я ставил столбики и прокладывал линию из верёвок что бы при возвращении не заблудиться. Вдобавок плюсы к атмосфере! Реально понимаешь, ты на один на все чёртовой станции, помощи ждать неоткуда. Помогает только таинственный мужчина, общающийся исключительно через странный аппарат (типа смс из 80-х). По сути он просто задаёт цели, мы выполняем. Также совет всем новичкам не пытайтесь обследовать всё сразу, вы всё равно попадёте во все домики по сюжету! 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=865178423
Вот так мы и путешествуем между отдельными зданиями станции, ищем припасы, вроде проводов, скотча и прочие что бы хоть как-то облегчить пребывание. Самые интересные чувства испытаешь в конце, когда уже закалился и даже в пургу находишь дорогу. Ощущаешь себя гораздо выше, говоришь себе- я справился, я смог, я выжил! Но вот сможете ли выжить вы, другой вопрос. Для самых-самых есть аж 4 вида сложности, на последней замерзаешь секунд за 30… В общем за интересные ощущения, за чувство одиночества могу похвалить. А вот за чертовски жуткие тормоза хочется двинуть кому-то палкой, полный ад! Fps проседает до 10-5 кадров бывает… Хотя графика нормальная, но по нынешним меркам отстала лет на 9. Помещения тоже, уж очень однотипные. Итог – неплохое приключение, без лоска, без революции, со слегка однотипным геймплем. Но если доходишь до конца, радости берёт своё. По традиции, сравниваю с другими похожим играми.

29294248.review:
Near Death was a game I picked up on sale with mild expectations but was actually blown away by. The premise is very simple but the devs manage to do a lot with it. The game reminded me a lot of Penumbra, with a monsterless metroidvania twist. The puzzles are all believable scenarios as you try and find your way across an ambandoned base and slowly bring enough systems back online to keep yourself from freezing to death while also forming a plan to get back to humanity. 

It all comes together to make a very immersive story that is surprisingly tense for your only enemy being nature itself. When I started the game I pretty much ignored using rope poles and light beacons since everything seemed easy enough to find just using the map and compass. But as the weather worsened and took a huge toll on visiblity and mobility those simple tools became life savers for traveling between the longer streches between some parts of the base.

All in all I'd highly recommend Near Death to anyone who enjoys a unique immersive experience. Although being trapped in an antartic base isnt a new premise, this is the most realistic representation of it I've seen so far. The game is short but it doesnt outlive its welcome, and a simple surprise they put at the end really gives you a great sense of accomplishment once you're on your final stretch home :) .
